fields.headline: Eurozone crisis: IMF admits mistakes over Greece bailout - as it happened
fields.body:
11.00pm BST

Key event

Debate over the IMF report into Greece will rage into Thursday. So I'll be back with another liveblog in a few hours :)

Until tomorrow morning, goodnight all, and thanks for reading and for the comments. GW

10.52pm BST

Mea Culpas: translated....

Here are a few mea culpas from the final section of the IMF report (p49 and 50), to ponder...

1) With regard to Fund involvement, the view expressed was that it would have been better if the crisis could have been resolved within the EU/euro zone, but neither the authorities nor the EC or ECB had the required program experience. The Fund’s experience in crisis resolution made it a necessary part of the process.

Translation: We'd rather have not been there at all. But they'd have done an even worse job without us.

2) Later, the possibility of Greece exiting the euro became a public debate by the euro partners, a discussion that should have occurred behind closed doors.

Translation: why in God's name wouldn't they shut up about Grexit?

3) The common view was that no-one could have predicted the depth and length of the recession. However, officials acknowledged that the program’s macroeconomic projections had risks to the downside that materialized in a context of political instability and deposit outflows.

Also, in calculating the effects of tax measures, price and income elasticities were underestimated and this reduced the revenue yield

Translation: Perhaps we should have known how bad things would be. But again, who knew better?...

4) With hindsight, greater effort should also have been made at the beginning of the program to privatize state assets and to clamp down on prominent tax evaders.

Translation: Greater effort could STILL be made to privative state assets and clamp down on prominent tax evaders

5) Consensus on the program has now improved with the coalition government. However, the crisis and the recession have had terrible consequences for Greece in terms of unemployment and have caused severe stress in society with extreme parties now gaining support.

Translation: Looks like we've helped to fuel support for a neo-nazi party. That wasn't in the programme.

10.37pm BST

Some more reaction to the report:

10.34pm BST

And this graph from the report shows how Greek wages dropped under the programme, as unemployment soared:

10.25pm BST

IMF: Bailout pain wasn't shared fairly across society

Another criticism of the bailout, is that the burden of adjustment "was not shared evenly across society".

In the public sector, while wages and bonuses were cut, "specific plans to downsize the number of civil servants were limited to a commitment to replace only 20 percent of those who retired."

The state enterprises also remained generously staffed, the report states.

Over in the private sector, the Troika had expected wage negotiations to push down labour costs. But this didn't happen:

The private sector sustained enormous job losses partly because wage setting mechanisms were not liberalized.

And the report also cites Greece's failure to clamp down harder on tax evasion by high income earners:

While the program recognized that it would take time to show results from improved tax administration, the absence of quick progress in collecting evaded taxes came at the cost of any demonstrable improvement in the equity of the tax burden.

9.59pm BST

Why taxpayers were left on the hook

On page 28 of the report (pdf), the IMF bluntly admits that the 2010 bailout was a "holding operation", and taxpapers paid the price.

Rather than just lending Athens €110bn, it would have been better to have imposed haircuts on borrowers then, in 2010. However, political opposition made it impossible, and gave private bondholders the time to shift out of Greek debt:

As the iMF admits:

Not tackling the public debt problem decisively at the outset or early in the program created uncertainty about the euro area’s capacity to resolve the crisis and likely aggravated the contraction in output.

An upfront debt restructuring would have been better for Greece although this was not acceptable to the euro partners. A delayed debt restructuring also provided a window for private creditors to reduce exposures and shift debt into official hands.

As seen earlier, this shift occurred on a significant scale and limited the bail-in of creditors when PSI* eventually took place, leaving taxpayers and the official sector on the hook.

* PSI = private sector involvment of 2011, when corporate creditors agreed to cut the Greek debt mountain by €200bn.

Updated at 10.00pm BST

9.53pm BST

Here's some early reaction to the IMF report tonight from City experts, financial journalists and eurocrisis watchers:

9.46pm BST

IMF: Greece may need more debt reduction

The IMF has also released its latest assessment of Greece -- and warned that European countries made need to make further debt write-offs to keep the Greek debt programme on track:

Here's the key paragraph (full statement here)

Directors expressed concern that public debt is projected to remain high well into the next decade and concurred with the assessment that macroeconomic risks are on the downside. 

In this context, Directors welcomed the assurances from Greece’s European partners that they will consider further measures and assistance, if necessary, to reduce debt to substantially below 110% of GDP by 2022, conditional on Greece’s full implementation of all commitments contained in the program.

Speaking on tonight's conference call, Poul Thomsen said he hoped that this commitment would encourage private investors to buy Greek debt. But if they get nervous, a more 'front-loaded' appoach may be needed.....

Updated at 9.46pm BST

9.36pm BST

Read the report yourself

You can read the full 50-page report yourself -- EX POST EVALUATION OF EXCEPTIONAL ACCESS UNDER THE 2010 STAND-BY ARRANGEMENT (pdf).

9.34pm BST

Greek 10-year bond yields - a historic guide

The report includes a handy reminder of the last three and a half years, using the backdrop of Greece's borrowing costs:

9.29pm BST

IMF defends Troika

Thomsen also denied that the reports says the Troika (the IMF-EU-ECB) did a bad job.

The report does not say that the Troika did not function well, it says it functioned very well...but clearly there could have been a better division of labour.

Thomsen added that the Troika functioned "surprisingly well" given it was made up of three different bodies, although clearly there's always room for improvement....

So let's check the report.....

And the final paragraph explains how the troika struggled to 'gel' and work in a 'co-ordinated' fashion:

The Troika reflects three different institutions. This sometimes posed coordination problems: the Fund made decisions in a structured fashion, while decision-making in the Euro Zone spanned Heads of State and multiple agencies and was more fragmented.Officials observed that it took time for the Troika to gel as a unit, for example, in formulating a common macro view, but in general, dealing with the Troika was fairly smooth. The Troika partners listened to each other and were well-prepared. However, detailed conditionality increased the coordination challenge. There was also sometimes a lack of continuity in the Troika teams. All-in-all, this exacerbated uncertainty and reduced the possibility for early agreements.

So, the Troika did its best, but struggled – and the dysfunctionality in the eurozone didn't help. That won't shock experienced watchers of the crisis either.

Updated at 6.58am BST

9.24pm BST

IMF: Grexit talk hurt Greece

Speculation over Greece's possible exit from the eurozone hampered the bailout, Poul Thomsen of the International Monetary Fund told reporters on the press conference.

Thomsen pinned some of the blame on those in Europe who talked about Grexit risks, saying they had helped to drive its economy down. This added to the impact of its austerity programme.

9.08pm BST

IMF's Thomsen: we would do things differently next time..

Poul Thomsen, the IMF's mission chief to Greece, is speaking on a conference call now.

Asked whether the IMF had made mistakes, Thomsen pointed to the 'multiplier' -- the number used when calculating the impact that spending cuts have on growth (and which clearly didn't work with Greece).

Themson said that the IMF had used calculations from the OECD, but now recognises that a larger multiplier is needed:

Certainly, there are things that we could have done differently.

If we did it again, we wouldn't use the same multiplier.

Updated at 6.57am BST

9.00pm BST

IMF report released

Breaking: the IMF report is out, and it admits that the Washington-based fund made a series of 'notable' errors over Greece's first bailout in 2010, including overestimating the impact of austerity.

The 50-page document admits that the programme created a much deeper recession than expected, driving unemployment higher than the Fund had forecast.

However, it argues that the bailout package was necessary and did achieve two key targets -- keeping Greece in the eurozone, and avoiding wider contagion.

The report cited several "notable failures" -- the long recession, the panic caused in the financial markets, and damage to Greece's banking sector as savers withdrew this money:

Market confidence was not restored, the banking system lost 30 percent of its deposits, and the economy encountered a much- deeper-than-expected recession with exceptionally high unemployment.

Public debt remained too high and eventually had to be restructured, with collateral damage for bank balance sheets that were also weakened by the recession. Competitiveness improved somewhat on the back of falling wages, but structural reforms stalled and productivity gains proved elusive.

The report reveals that IMF officials changed their criterion, to ensure that Greece passed its rules for "debt sustainability". Subsequently, Greece's fast-shrinking economy missed the macro-economic targets.

The Fund's report is also critical of the way the Greek programme was handled, saying "depth of ownership of the program and the capacity to
implement structural reforms were overestimated".

It also admits that it struggled to cope with a bailout programme within a currency union:

A particular challenge is to find ways to translate promises of conditional assistance from partner countries into formal program agreements.

And finally, the Fund pointed to political challenges -- and implied that the Greek government hasn't played straight with the IMF during bailout talks.

It said:

Greece’s recent experience demonstrates the importance of spreading the burden of adjustment across different strata of society in order to build support for a program. The obstacles encountered in implementing reforms also illustrate the critical importance of ownership of a program,
a lesson that is common to the findings of many previous EPEs.
Other lessons drawn concern the need to find ways to streamline the Troika process in the future and for Fund staff to be more skeptical about official data during regular surveillance.

The IMF is holding a conference call now... I'll post some highlights shortly, along with more details of the report....

Updated at 7.02am BST

8.31pm BST

Still expecting the IMF report to be released this evening – perhaps quite soon....

9pm BST in fact

Updated at 8.33pm BST

8.03pm BST

Other newspaper coverage

The IMF started the process of admitting errors over Greece a few months ago, when its economics staff revealed that it may have underestimated the impact of austerity. The FT writes, though, that this new report goes further:

Although the IMF has made such arguments in public recently – saying that it may have underestimated the “multiplier effect” that tough austerity measures have on economic growth – the report says that Greece was a particularly problematic case because of the government’s administrative weaknesses.

While the Daily Telegraph points out that the report could have implications for the way other bailout packages are handled in future.

The IMF report is scathing about the so-called “troika”, a body that was created when the fund joined forces with the European Commission and the European Central Bank to run the first €110bn Greek bailout in 2010.

The indictment of the “troika” will have wider resonance because as well as administering Greece it oversees the economies of the other bailed-out eurozone countries - Ireland, Portugal and Cyprus.

Updated at 8.05pm BST

7.55pm BST

As regular eurozone watchers will know, the original €110bn bailout for Greece in 2010 was followed by another a year later, which included a massive debt writedown by the private sector.

That writeoff is the largest sovereign default ever. Officials insist that a repeat will not be allowed for other eurozone nations (in Cyprus, of couse, large bank depositors were 'bailed in' instead).

6.23pm BST

Greek officials welcome IMF report

In Athens, government officials reacted with barely disguised glee to the news that the International Monetary Fund made mistakes in its first bailout, three years. ago.

Insiders say that the report is particularly critical of the European Union, and also confirms what Greeks have long suspected -- that its first bailout was a major blunder.

In Athens, Helena Smith has been speaking to officials, and reports:

The report confirms what Greek officials have long said: that the first bailout of uncompromising budget cuts and tax increases, the price of €110bn in emergency funds in May 2010, was the wrong prescription for a country not only batting a monumental debt load but rampant tax evasion and a flourishing black economy.

Under the weight of such measures – applied across the board and hitting the poorest hardest – the economy, they said, was always bound to dive into an economic death spiral. “For too long they [troika officials] refused to accept that the programme was simply off-target by hiding behind our failure to implement structural reforms,” said one insider. “Now that reforms are being applied they’ve had to accept the bitter truth.”

The Greek media recently quoted IMF managing director Christine Lagarde describing 2011 as a “lost year” partly because of miscalculations by the EU and IMF.

The authoritative Kathimerini newspaper said the new report identified a number of “mistakes” including the failure of creditors to agree to a restructuring of Greece’s debt burden earlier – a failure that had had a disastrous effect on its macro-economic assumptions.

One well-placed official at the Greek finance ministry told Helena:

From what we understand the IMF singles out the EU for criticism in its handling of the problem more than anything else.

But acknowledgement of these mistakes will help us. It has already helped cut some slack and it will help us get what we really need which is a haircut on our debt next year.

6.22pm BST

An IMF spokeswoman said has confirmed that the Fund plans to publish "a number of papers on Greece later today". She added:

The board met last Friday to discuss several documents on Greece including the review of its programme and its annual economic assessment.

Updated at 6.22pm BST

6.15pm BST

A bad day for the markets

The news of the IMF's mea culpa over Greece hit the wires as Europe's stock markets finished a bad day with heavy losses. The FTSE 100 lost over 2%, or 139 points with all-but three shares losing ground.

The selloff was triggered by renewed fears that America will start unwinding its stimulus package this summer, and the hefty selloff in Japan early this morning (when the Nikkei slid almost 4%). The futures market suggests a similar slide tomorrow, which would put the index into 'bear market' territory.

There's a full market report here, by my colleague Nick Fletcher.

Over on Wall Street, the Dow Jones has dropped below the 15,000 mark for the first time in a month.

5.36pm BST

IMF to admit 'serious lapses' over Greece

The International Monetary Fund is poised to admit making mistakes in its handling of the first Greek bailout in 2010, according to an exclusive running on the Wall Street Journal.

The report (online here), claims that an internal IMF document will admit that it underestimated the impact of the country's austerity programme, and also that rules were bent to keep Greece within the programme.

The document, which we're hearing could be published tonight, also claims that serious mistakes were made by officials.

Here's a flavour of the WSJ's story:

In an internal document marked "strictly confidential," the IMF said it badly underestimated the damage that its prescriptions of austerity would do to Greece's economy, which has been mired in recession for years.

But the fund also stressed that the response to the crisis, coordinated with the European Union, bought time to limit the fallout for the rest of the 17-nation euro area.

The IMF said that it bent its own rules to make Greece's burgeoning debt seem sustainable and that, in retrospect, the country failed on three of the four IMF criteria to qualify for assistance.

Full story here: IMF to Admit Mistakes on Greece Bailout

And here's more highlights from the WSJ's Matina Stevis, who broke the story:

Updated at 5.52pm BST

5.26pm BST

Greece hoping for bumper tourism

More news from Greece where officials are devising a new strategy to boost a sector that is vital to regenerating the economy.

Helena Smith reports that the initiative has been sparked by record numbers of tourist arrivals this year.

It’s official: tourism, Greece’s biggest industry after shipping, is experiencing a renaissance. For the first time since the outbreak of the crisis, figures show the country being braced for a bumper year with some 17 million visitors due to fly in. In Athens, alone, industry figures are reporting a 10 percent increase – a huge boost for a capital that barely a year ago was associated solely with street riots and strikes. “It is going to be a bumper year,” said Andreas Andreadis, who heads the Association of Hellenic Tourism Enterprises (SETE). “The crisis has made Greek enterprises, everyone, much more aware. Greek society understands that tourism can help the country get out of the crisis, by first of all creating jobs,” he told me.

Tourism, which contributed around €32bn to economic output in 2012, accounts for almost 17% of GDP. Roughly 780,000 people are employed in the sector. Andreadis, who has been widely credited with innovatively bumping up the private sector’s role in marketing the country – previously promoted by lacklustre state bodies – wants to transform Greece into one of the ten best quality destinations worldwide. To that end, Greece must think outside the box by turning away from the mass market, where deteriorating competiveness has lessened its appeal, and tapping larger, long-haul emerging source markets such as the US, China and Russia. Moves are already afoot.

Thanks to a lifting of visa restrictions “13,000 visas in Russia are being issued for Greece every day,” he said. “The volume is so high that SETE has employed 20 of its own people just to help stamp visas.” Russian arrivals at regional airports, as a result, have already shot up by 230%.

The increase in arrivals is vital to helping austerity-hit Greeks, now blighted by the worst unemployment rate in the euro zone, survive the next year.

Last year, the 15.5 million tourists who visited Greece spent 650 euro on average. This year, the hope is that 17 million will spend an average €670. By 2021, Andreadis says, the aim is to attract 24 million tourists who will spend an average €800 – €50bn in total – thus ensuring jobs for around one million people.

 “Better quality will be central to generating that demand,” he said adding that a new PR and branding strategy, focusing on luxury tourism, would also be vital to turning tourism – and the economy – around.

4.03pm BST

Speaking of bear markets....

This graph shows how the RTS Index has slid this year:

3.53pm BST

US economics catch-up

Various gobbets of economic news from the US this afternoon.

1) 135,000 private jobs were created in America last month, a slight increase on April's reading but lower than expected. Economists said it was consistent with only slow employment growth (see graph above - more from Marketwatch here).

2) The US service sector grew faster last month, with its ISM non-manufacturing index rising to 53.7 in May, from 53.1 in April. However, the employment index component of the measure dropped.

Paul Dales of Capital Economics said the IMS reading was a "relief", but warned that when Monday's weak manufacturing data is included the US economy is probably slowing.

3) US factory orders rose by 1% in April, reversing March's 4.7% fall.

Following all this, shares are down across Europe's financial markets this afternoon after Wall Street opened in the red.

The FTSE 100 is down 118 points, or 1.8%, at 6439, with the Dow Jones off 72 points (-0.5%).

As my colleague Nick Fletcher writes here, markets were already weak on a growing number of comments from US Federal Reserve members that its bond buying programme - a key support for share prices - might gradually come to an end. The 3.8% drop on the Nikkei overnight also caused alarm - much lower and it will be an official bear market.

2.33pm BST

Meanwhile over in Athens our correspondent Helena Smith reports there has been a lively protest by disabled Greeks against austerity measures outside the prime minister’s office. 

She writes:

Hundreds of blind Greeks shouted furiously against the stinging effects of austerity in a demonstration deliberately held to coincide with the arrival of auditors from Greece's troika of creditors at the EU, ECB and IMF. Standing behind a row of police vans and policemen despatched to keep them at bay from prime minister Antonis Samaras’ office, the protestors urged the coalition government to “stick to its commitments” and press for the survival of disability benefits in talks with the officials.

Many held protest sheets printed in braille against a backdrop of a huge banner deploring the “200bn euro that has been given to banks.”

“Disabled people in this country have paid a very high price for the crisis,” said Giorgos Mitropoulos, vice president of Greece’s association for the blind, a mega-phone in one hand. “We have suffered cuts that no one in our situation should suffer. I hope the prime minister listens.”

2.11pm BST

Latvia's economy -- far from equal

Latvia's entry to the euro club comes four years since it took a €7.5bn bailout from the IMF and the EU.

The financial crisis of 2008 burst a credit bubble that had swelled over several years, triggering a real estate crash and anti-government riots in the country, and the resignation of the prime minister.

A new government installed in 2009 imposed tough spending cuts and wage reductions, helped to drive Latvia into a deep recession, with the jobless rate rising towards 20%.

The economy is now growing strongly again (as the EC was keen to point to this morning). Latvia's GDP increased by 1.2% in the first three months of 2013, defying the 0.2% contraction across the eurozone. The economy is 5.6% larger than a year ago.

But the country, of around 2.2m people, still suffers high poverty levels and income inequality.

According to the Baltic Centre for Economic Policy Studies, over 30% of the population is classified as “severely materially deprived,” in 2010. That means they can't afford to pay rent, food bills or utility costs. This is the worst figure in the EU.

And as the Toronto Star reported in March, there is a yawning gap between rich and poor in Latvia. Especially outside Riga, the capital city:

Take a trip east out of Riga and you will see the faces of austerity.

Small cottages and worn farmhouses poke through the deep snow. They form hamlets or villages named Pededze, Aluksne, Liepna and Kuprava.

Everyone seems to be out of work. Wood stoves are used for heat — wood is free and abundant. Most houses have chickens and a couple cows to supplement paltry monthly government assistance cheques of about 35 lats.

Almost all of the young people have fled — to Italy, Germany or Spain.

In Kuprava, about 10 minutes from the Russian border, , the official unemployment rate is 20 per cent. But even municipal officers in the town of 800 admit the real figure is much higher.

More here: In Latvia, a tough-love economy leaves losers behind

Updated at 2.14pm BST

1.15pm BST

Latvian PM: We'll grow faster in the eurozone

Over in Riga, the Latvian prime minister has welcomed being given the go-ahead to adopt the euro from next January.

PM Valdis Dombrovskis told a news conference that the country could look forward to more rapid economic growth inside the euro area.

Dombrovskis said:

Joining the euro zone will foster Latvia's economic growth, for sure.

He predicted that more foreign investment would flow into the country, and that sovereign credit rating agencies could upgrade Latvia once it joins the euro area.

12.44pm BST

Rehn: Latvia is not Cyprus

An important question for Olli Rehn at the Brussels press conference:

Given Latvia's banking sector has a high reliance on foreign savers, particularly from CIS countries (the former Soviet Republics), are we risking a repeat of Cyprus?

Rehn says this is a pertinent issue, but denies that the two countries are comparable. Latvia's total financial sector is much smaller.

In Cyprus, the relative size of the banking sector was 800% of GDP, while in Latvia it is below 150% of GDP.

On average, the eurozone's financial sector was 356% of GDP in 2011, he adds.

Rehn added that Latvia has a long tradition of servicing non-domestic banking clients, mainly corporate from CIS countries.

And that does pose "additional challenges", due to the cross-border nature of these dealings, he adds....

(as flagged up earlier, analysts believe as much as half of Latvia's deposits come from outside the country)

12.31pm BST

Finally, Rehn talks about the progress made by the Baltic states - remembering that he first visited Latvia 30 years ago.

The area has made strong progress since, to reach the heart of Europe, he says.

12.30pm BST

Rehn adds that Latvia will become a fully signed-up member of Europe's new banking supervision and bank resulutions regulations.

and repeats that the decision to join the euro is "a strong signal" to the euro area, the financial markets, and the world at large.

It underlines the strength of the euro...and that economic rewards play off.

12.25pm BST

Rehn: Latvia is a 'vote of confidence' in the euro

Latvia's decision to join the eurozone is also a vote of confidence in the single currency, Olli Rehn says.

Those who thought the single currency would break up were 'behind the curve and wrong', he declares.

Updated at 12.26pm BST

12.24pm BST

Olli Rehn is speaking in Brussels now. After giving his "best greetings to journalists in Riga", he confirms that Latvia is ready to adopt the euro from January next year.

He says Latvia has achieved a high degree of convergence with the eurozone (see 11.31am for details).

Latvia shows that a country can overcome macroeconomic challenges and emerge stronger, he says, talking about the tough fiscal cuts implemented since the financilal crisis started

Latvia is on track to be the fastest-growing country in the EU this year, he says.

12.16pm BST

Latvia to join the euro - EC

The European Commission has confirmed in the last few moments that Latvia can join the euro from January 2014, becoming the 18th member of the currency union.

That's despite the concerns over high levels of foreign savings in its banking sector (see 11.31am).

In a statement, the EC said:

The Commission considers that Latvia fulfills the conditions for the adoption of the euro.

Member states will sign the decision off, on July 9.

Olli Rehn, European Commissioner for monetary union, will discuss the issue shortly (there'll be a live feed here).

11.47am BST

EC responds to Chinese wine threat

Over in Brussels, the EC has criticised China's threat to impose new duties on European wine (see 11.11am).

A spokesman denied that unfairly subsidised crates of the stuff are being sold at bargain prices to Chinese consumers:

And confirmation that France could bear the brunt of Beijing's anger, having actually supported imposing levies on Chinese solar panel makers:

11.31am BST

Latvia gets ECB nod to join euro despite ECB concerns

Breaking: Latvia is to become the 18th member of the eurozone after the European Central Bank gave its blessing, despite concerns over high levels of foreign deposits in its banking sector.

An official statement is expected from the Commission shortly.

In a statement (online here), the ECB said that Latvia meets its convergence criteria, but warned that the "longer-term sustainability of its economic convergence" is of concern.

It urged the country "lock in" recent competitive gains by keeping a cap on wage growth (or "avoiding a renewed increase in unit labour cost growth", as it put it).

The ECB also called for improved economic governance, adding:

It is crucial that a comprehensive policy toolkit is available to deal with risks to financial stability, including those stemming from the reliance of a significant part of the banking sector on non-resident deposits as a source of funding.

The reference to "non-resident deposits" brings back memories of the Cyprus panic.

Back in April, Otilia Simkova of Eurasia Group explained that Latvia's actually has a higher ratio of overseas savings. She wrote (in the FT):

Foreign money, especially from Russia, has been trickling in.

The level of non-resident deposits is heading for 50% of total deposits. By comparison, at its peak this year, the level of non-resident deposits in Cyprus was just 37%.

Here's some early reaction:

Updated at 11.34am BST

11.11am BST

Days of wine and rowing, as China hits back in trade dispute

The prospect of a full-blown trade war between the European Union and China is looming closer today.

Beijing retailiated against new tariffs on its solar panel industry, announced on Tuesday, by announcing that it would consider imposing new duties on EU wine.

The tit-for-tat move raises the prospect of stiff price rises for bottles from countries such as Franch and Italy, at a time when Europe is hoping to export its way back to growth.

From Brussels, our Europe editor Ian Traynor explained:

A Europe-China trade war took firmer shape on Wednesday when Beijing announced it has opened an anti-dumping inquiry into EU wine exports a day after Brussels imposed tariffs on Chinese solar panels.

Beijing's move came after weeks of intense lobbying against Karel De Gucht, the EU commissioner for trade, who resisted fierce German pressure not to impose the sanction and to give more time for negotiations.

The Chinese strongly criticised the EU decision on solar panels, voicing "resolute opposition", adding that "We hope the EU will further show their sincerity and show flexibility, through consultations to find mutually acceptable solutions".

De Gucht appeared to show flexibility yesterday, imposing the solar panel levy at under 12% for the first few weeks. It will rise to almost 50% in August if the two sides can't reach a deal soon over the alleged dumping of unfairly cheap Chinese solar panels on the European market.

Here's the full story: China launches inquiry into European wine exports as trade war fears grow.

10.26am BST

Eurozone recession confirmed

It's official – the eurozone shrank by 0.2% in the first three months of 2013. That's in line with the preliminary reading from last month, confirming the eurozone lagged other major economies in Q1 2013.

As explained at 9.51am, today's service sector data suggests the eurozone kept shrinking in May

Howard Archer of IHS Global Insight reckons it's "far from inconceivable" that the recession will continue this quarter, adding:

The hope is that it will be spared this fate by improved growth in Germany which should be helped by a rebound in construction activity after it was held back by the bad weather in the first quarter.

And new shopping data, just released, add to the gloomy picture. Retail sales fell by 0.5% month-on-month in April, showing a 1.1% decline over the last year.

Updated at 10.43am BST

9.55am BST

UK service sector roars ahead....

At the risk of drowning in data, the UK service sector grew much faster than expected in. Its PMI of 54.9 for May, up from 52.9 in April, showed the fastest monthly growth since March 2012.

The rise was partly attributed to better weather following Britain's god-awful winter. Markit's Chris Williamson said the UK economy had "moved up a gear, with all cylinders firing".

Economists and City traders welcomed the news:

9.51am BST

Markit: The eurozone downturn eases

The eurozone remains stuck in recession, but the downturn in its private sector eased in May, according to data provider Markit's latest survey of companies across the region.

Its composite PMI, based on today's service sector and yesterday's manufacturing data, came in at 47.7, up from April’s 46.9, which means it moved closer to growing again. 

But only one of its four largest economies, Germany, actually saw its private sector expand.

Germany: 50.2 -- a 2-month high [where >50 = growth]
Spain: 47.2 -- a 23-month high
Italy: 46.6 -- unchanged
France: 44.6 -- 5-month high

The data also showed that new orders fell and job losses rose.

Chris Williamson, chief economist at Markit, said the data was encouraging, but hardly a reason to cheer -- as the eurozone's long recession was clearly continuing.

The final PMI confirms the message from the earlier flash reading that the eurozone remains gripped in the longest recession since the birth of the single currency, set to endure a seventh successive quarter of decline in
the second quarter.

The survey points to GDP falling by 0.2%, similar to the decline seen in the first quarter.

Policymakers and politicians will nevertheless seek solace in the fact that the rate of decline has now eased for two consecutive months, and that Germany is stabilising. Downturns have also eased in France, Italy
and especially Spain since earlier in the year.

However, the reality is that the region lacks any growth drivers, making it difficult to believe that anything better than a mere stabilisation of economic activity remains unlikely for the foreseeable future.

9.25am BST

French and German service sectors contract

No relief for France in today's data -- its service sector kept shrinking at the same rate with a PMI of 44.3, unchanged from April.

And Germany's PMI was slightly weaker than expected at 49.7. That indicates a small contraction again, but a little bit better than April (49.6).

8.52am BST

Italian service sector worsens

Italy's service sector shrank at a faster rate, according to this morning's PMI data. At 46.5, the reading was weaker than April's 47.0, suggesting the sector shrank at a faster rate.

Prime minister Enrico Letta's challenge doesn't get any easier....

8.40am BST

Spanish service sector slump slows

Spain's service sector shrank again in May for the 23rd month in a row, but at the slowest rate in almost two years.

Markit's service sector PMI for Spain (the first in a series this morning) came in at 47.3, an improvement on April's 44.4. Although new business and employment fell, and optimism weakened, the data may show that better times are ahead.

Andrew Harker, economist at Markit, said the data provided "some cause for optimism":

Activity moved closer to stabilisation than at any time since mid-2011.

Following on from a similar trend in the manufacturing PMI data, maybe we are starting to see some light at the end of the tunnel. Developments in the wider euro area economy over the next few months will probably be key to whether this turns out to be a false dawn or the start of a sustained recovery

We'll get data from the rest of the eurozone over the next 30 minutes....
 

8.23am BST

Tesco hit by European austerity

In the corporate world, supermarket chain Tesco has blamed austerity measures for falling sales at its European stores.

Tesco reported a 5.5% drop in sales (excluding fuel) in Europe this morning, and said consumers in its international markets continue to face "challenging" conditions.

It explained:

In all markets, consumers continue to exercise caution in their shopping habits, as they face the direct impact of a variety of austerity measures linked to the tough economic environment.

The impact of these external pressures increased in Ireland, with a significant reduction in consumer sentiment and spending following the announced introduction of a Local Property Tax on residential properties.

Like for like sales in Ireland were down by 3%. Tesco's European arm also covers Hungary, the Czech Republic, Poland, Slovakia and Turkey - which suffered the biggest drop (-15%), so eurozone austerity can't take all the blame....

It also reported a drop in UK sales -- we'll have more on this on the site shortly...

Updated at 8.29am BST

8.11am BST

European markets down - Fed fears linger....

As feared, European stock markets have also opened lower, following Japan's 3.8% drop overnight.

The main indices are down around 0.7%, so nothing too dramatic, with the FTSE 100 dropping 46 points to 6512.

Michael McCarthy, senior market strategist at CMC Markets, said investors are still pondering when central banks such as the Federal Reserve might slow their electronic money-printing programmes. Friday's US jobs data looms, as McCarthy explained:

The “will they, won’t they” game of stimulus continues to dominate markets. US markets softened ahead of the data on Friday night, and Japanese investors roiled exporters’ shares after comments from PM Abe were interpreted as too cautious.

Updated at 8.15am BST

8.03am BST

Key event

The Nikkei is now on the brink of a bear-market, having fallen around 19% from its peak last month:

7.41am BST

Abe unveils new growth plan

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the latest events across the eurozone and the world economy.

It's a busy morning for data. New services sector surveys will show how Europe's private firms fared in May, while revised GDP figures should confirm that the eurozone remains in recession.

But first, Japan's prime minister has unveiled the next stage of his economic recovery plan - to an underwhelmed reception. The Nikkei slid by 3.8% after Shinzo Abe fired the so-called 'Third Arrow', while the yen remains below the ¥100 mark against the US dollar.

in a much-anticipated speech, Abe said he would:

• create special economic zones to lure foreign businesses to Japan. These areas could offer lower tax rates and other incentives.

• Fully liberalise the retail electricity market

• Increase investment in power related infrastructure to 30 trillion yen over the next decade

• Raise incomes by 3 percent annually (thus keeping wages above Abe's 2% inflation target)

Abe said that final point was a clear priority, telling the nation:

That's because the aim of our growth strategy is nothing other than to create jobs for enthusiastic people and raise take-home pay for those who are working hard.

In short, to let households benefit. That's the point.

Further details of the plan are expected in the weeks ahead. But the strategy did not wow Japan's markets today – suggesting Abenomics may be losing its sparkle.

Some analysts said the plan didn't sound ambitious enough, while others questioned whether the income growth target could be met while also encouraging firms to hire more temporary (cheaper?) wokers.

As Sophia University professor Koichi Nakano put it:

His government is very good at PR strategy, but it really does look more like a campaign platform rather than anything worthy of the name of economic policies.

With the world watching Abe's plans with nervous interest, the Nikkei's fall will probably hit shares in Europe this morning.

Reaction to follow, along with other events through the day...

webTitle: IMF 'to admit mistakes' in handling Greek debt crisis and bailout

fields.standfirst: Internal reports to suggest International Monetary Fund underestimated the damage austerity would cause to the eurozone country
fields.body:
The International Monetary Fund is to admit that it has made serious mistakes in the handling of the sovereign debt crisis in Greece, according to internal reports due to be published later on Wednesday.

Documents presented to the Fund's board last Friday will reveal that the Washington-based organisation underestimated the damage austerity would cause to the eurozone country, which has required two bailouts in the past three years.

The Wall Street Journal reported that the papers would say that financial support from the Fund, the European Central Bank and the European Commission had bought time for Greece but had only been made possible because the IMF had bent its own rules to make the country's debt look more sustainable than it was. According to the WSJ report, Greece failed to meet three of the Fund's four tests to qualify for help.

A Fund spokeswoman said: "We will be publishing a number of papers on Greece later today. The board met last Friday to discuss several documents on Greece including the review of its programme and its annual economic assessment."

Greece became the first eurozone nation to require a bailout by the international community in 2010, but needed a second round of financial assistance in early 2012 when a deep recession and high interest payments threatened to send its debts spiralling out of control.

The so-called troika of the IMF, ECB and EC forced private sector bondholders to write down the value of their Greek bonds in an attempt to bring the country's debts down to sustainable levels of 120% of national income by 2020.

Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the Fund, has said many times over the past year that Greece should now be in a position to pay off its debts, but the WSJ reports that IMF staff believe this cannot be said with any certainty.

In Athens, officials reacted with barely disguised glee to the news.

The report confirms what Greek officials have long said: that the first bailout of uncompromising budget cuts and tax increases, the price of 110 bn euro in emergency funds in May 2010, was the wrong prescription for a country not only batting a monumental debt load but rampant tax evasion and a flourishing black economy.

Under the weight of such measures – applied across the board and hitting the poorest hardest – the economy, they said, was always bound to dive into an economic death spiral. "For too long they [troika officials] refused to accept that the programme was simply off-target by hiding behind our failure to implement structural reforms," said one insider. "Now that reforms are being applied they've had to accept the bitter truth."

The Greek media recently quoted IMF managing director Christine Lagarde describing 2011 as a "lost year" partly because of miscalculations by the EU and IMF. The authoritative Kathimerini newspaper said the report identified a number of "mistakes" including the failure of creditors to agree to a restructuring of Greece's debt burden earlier – a failure that had had a disastrous effect on its macro-economic assumptions.

"From what we understand the IMF singles out the EU for criticism in its handling of the problem more than anything else," said one well-placed official at the Greek finance ministry. "But acknowledgement of these mistakes will help us. It has already helped cut some slack and it will help us get what we really need which is a haircut on our debt next year.

webTitle: ENRC investors block share buybacks

fields.standfirst: Decision at the annual general meeting in London was seen as an attempt to restrict the board's power to influence the share price as founders seek to bring the company back into private hands
fields.body:
Shareholders in the Kazakh miner Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation have voted to prevent the board having the power to buy back company shares.

The decision at the annual general meeting in London was seen as an attempt to restrict the board's power to influence the share price, as three billionaire founders – the largest shareholders – seek to buy back the company.

A trio of oligarchs, Patokh Chodiev, Alijan Ibragimov and Alexander Machkevitch, are leading a bid to bring the troubled company back into private ownership. ENRC, subject of an investigation by the Serious Fraud Office over fraud, bribery and corruption allegations, received its prestigious London listing in 2007. On Monday an independent committee set up by ENRC's board to evaluate the bid, agreed to extend the deadline of the buyout bid to 24 June.

"There can be no certainty that an offer on ENRC will be made," company chairman Gerhard Ammann told the annual meeting. Ammann, who became chair in April after a boardroom exodus, also insisted ENRC was making "every effort to get to the bottom of [the SFO] allegations".

At the meeting, three proposals that would have given the board the power to buy back shares failed to win the necessary 75% of votes to pass. None of ENRC's billionaire founders, who own 43% of the mining company, was present at the meeting.

Last month, ENRC's independent committee rejected an initial offer that valued the company at $5bn (£3.2bn), saying that it undervalued the company.

The company's shares are worth about 244p, a sharp drop from the 560p in 2007.

ENRC has attracted criticism for its unusual ownership structure, with only 18% of its shares available in the free float for general investors to buy. One such shareholder, Victor De Souza, told the annual meeting he was dissatisfied with the performance of the company. "It is very disappointing that they have stopped paying a dividend."

webTitle: FTSE 100 finishes more than 2% lower on Fed fears, Japan and Australian growth worries

fields.standfirst: Concerns grow that US may begin winding down bond buying programme, while global economy still under pressure
fields.body:
Leading shares fell sharply on concerns that the US Federal Reserve may soon turn off the money tap and disappointment about Japan's plans to stimulate its economy.

Worse than expected Australian growth figures also hit sentiment, knocking mining shares in particular.

Despite a mixed economic picture from the US - including an ADP employment report showing a lower than expected 135,000 increase in private payrolls in May compared to estimates of 165,000 - the main concern was that the Federal Reserve's bond buying programme could start to be wound down. The markets have been banking on central banks continuing their measures to boost the global economy, but comments from a number of Fed members - most recently Dallas Fed president Richard Fisher and Kansas City's Esther George - suggested an end could be in sight.

In Japan pledges from prime minister Shinzo Abe to boost incomes and set up special economic zones disappointed investors expecting more action to boost the country's economy. After falling 3.8% overnight on Tuesday, the Nikkei futures were predicting a similar fall when the market reopened.

With the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 180 points or more than 1% by the time London closed, the FTSE 100 finished 139.27 points lower at 6419.31, a 2% decline. This marked the third triple digit fall in less than two weeks. On Thursday come key meetings at the Bank of England and European Central Bank, while Friday sees the latest US non-farm payroll data.

As Australia announced first quarter GDP growth of 0.6% - less than the forecast 0.8% - mining shares were among the leading fallers. Anglo American lost 64.5p to £14.54, while Fresnillo fell 49p to £11.16.

Elsewhere Tesco lost 18.85p to 345.6p after its trading update missed City forecasts, while a number of companies saw their shares go ex-dividend, including National Grid, down 50.5p at 740p, and Associated British Foods, 28p lower at £18.39.

Aberdeen Asset Management dropped 26.4p to 437.5p in the wake of Tuesday's news that director Anne Richards had sold more than £6m worth of shares. UBS has removed the company from its key call list but remain buyers.

Arm continued its recent weakness on worries about growing competition in its key tablet market from Intel, down 31p at 893p. But Bank of America Merrill Lynch said:

Simon Segars, Arm's upcoming chief executive, presented at our global tech conference yesterday. When asked about Intel's win at Samsung for a 10'' tablet, Mr Segars commented that Samsung has a tradition to use multiple suppliers and that not all Android apps run on x86 CPUs, potentially hindering user experience.
Arm recently raised its 2020 royalty revenues compound annual growth rate guidance. Mr Segars explained that Arm raised its guidance due to 1) expected share gains in existing and new markets, 2) higher royalty rates and 3) confidence in the underlying growth rate of Arm's core markets. We also believe Arm gave this guidance probably knowing fully well that Intel had won a tablet socket at Samsung. This indicates, in our view, how confident Arm's management is in the long term growth trajectory of its business. We see the recent weakness in the stock as a particular buying opportunity as we believe that Arm's ecosystem is likely to prevail long term.

Wolseley was one of the few gainers, up 15p at £31.60 following Tuesday's decline on caution about its European business.

Among the mid-caps packaging group RPC, which makes plastic jars and bottles for the likes of Heinz and Nescafe, added 8.1p to 407.7p, despite a 5% fall in full year profits to £76.3m. The company suffered from high polymer prices and a weak euro - some three quarters of its revenue comes from Europe. But it said it would benefit from recent falls in raw material prices and expected a cost cutting programme to bring in £12m of annual savings by 2015. Paul Jones at Panmure Gordon moved from hold to buy and raised his target price from 466p to 496p. He said:

Results to March 2013 are in line with our expectations, and suggest solid progress in both the current year and to March 2015 given the background scenario of cost reductions and efficiency improvements. Resin prices have fallen in recent months – which is a positive – and we believe delayed product launches and additional volume growth could also be a positive for the current year.
The potential for dividend growth looks better than previously expected given cash flows, and opportunities for bolt-ons looks promising given RPC's firepower and track record of integration.

Moneysupermarket.com lost 10.7p to 197p on news that founder Simon Nixon - who moved to a non-executive role in April - planned to sell a 14.8% stake in the business. The company is also returning £70m to shareholders with a special dividend of 12.92p a share. It also issued an upbeat trading statement. David Reynolds at Jefferies said:

Investors will welcome the increased liquidity, the punchy return of cash and whilst the brief trading update 'in line and revenues up in excess of 10% year on year' won't blow one's socks off - we look for 10.4% revenue growth for 2013 - it is in line.

Hedge fund group Man slumped nearly 17%, down 19.45p to 97.05p, after it said its flagship product AHL saw its net asset value fall by 6.1% last week, one of its biggest weekly declines.

Finally LiDCO leapt more than 18% to 11.375p after a successful trial of its computer-based technology which monitors the amount of blood flowing around the body during and after surgery. A study published in the British Journal of Surgery showed that the company's monitor improved recovery rates for patients undergoing open liver surgery, reducing the time patients needed to stay in hospital by three days.

Analyst Keith Redpath at the company's broker finnCap said:

The results follow on from the recent announcement from Ashford and St Peter's NHS Foundation Trust about reducing length of stay in colorectal surgery patients using [LiDCO's technology]. These trials further reinforce LiDCO's position in the current NHS initiative to ensure intraoperative fluid management in high risk surgery is adopted, providing the clinical validation necessary to support clinicians making the choice of appropriate technology for their needs.

fields.standfirst: Appointment of Richard Pym underlines Co-operative Group's determination to turn around banking arm
fields.body:
The Co-operative Group has bolstered its board with the appointment of a new finance director. It has also signalled its determination to remain in the financial services business by naming a new chairman for its loss-making banking arm.

As talks with regulators continue about finding a solution to plug a capital shortfall in its bank of as much as £1.8bn, the Co-op named Richard Pym as its chairman. Pym, who runs a bailed-out banking division for the government, said his new appointment would ensure the Co-op would continue to "provide customers with an alternative choice to the traditional banks".

The finance director of the supermarket chain Morrisons, Richard Pennycook, is also joining as interim finance director of the Co-op group, which spans pharmacists, supermarkets and funeral homes.

Pennycook, is credited with creating a four-year turnaround plan for the supermarket chain after its troubled takeover of Safeway. His recruitment could signal a wave of cost-cutting measures across the Co-op group.

They are a latest in sweeping management changes at the 165-year-old mutual which only last month installed Euan Sutherland, from B&Q, as chief executive, replacing life-long Co-op employee Peter Marks.

Sutherland said the bank was now "in very good hands" after the recruitment of Pym alongside the new boss of the bank, Niall Booker, the former HSBC banker appointed last week. Booker spent his career at HSBC before quitting in 2011 when he was running the US arm which was this week accused by New York of ignoring a law designed to help homeowners struggling with loans during a period when he was charge.

Co-op, plunged into uncertainty after a potentially devastating six notch downgrade to junk status, has stopped lending to small businesses to preserve capital. Pym has so far refused to disclose if the bank intended to resume this activity once the capital situation was rectified.

He told the Guardian he intended to take pay cut at UKAR, which runs the bailed-out parts of Bradford & Bingley and Northern Rock, where he will remain as chairman as he will be freeing up time to devote to the Co-op. Pym has also quit as a non-executive director of the commercial property investment firm British Land as he takes on a role at the Co-op. His new job might be regarded as a full-time position given the scale of the issues facing a bank that analysts at Barclays have estimated could have a capital shortfall of as much as £1.8bn.

Even before taking up the Co-op chairmanship, Pym had announced he would take a 5% cut to his £237,500 fee from UKAR, which exists to run down the loans granted by B&B and Northern Rock.

Pym, whose appointment is subject to formal regulatory approval, said: "We are clearly focused on actions to strengthen the bank's balance sheet and resolving the current underlying issues.

"This will allow us to continue to provide customers with an alternative choice to the traditional banks."

He added that the group's ethical stance towards banking would remain a key marketing element.

By juggling two chairmanships in the financial services industry, Pym acknowledged that potential conflicts of interest would need to be managed. "I have may to excuse myself [from some discussions]," said Pym. "The two banks are completely different. UKAR is not looking for new customers."

webTitle: Tesco sales tumble on horsemeat scandal

fields.standfirst: Britain's biggest supermarket hit by sales slide in nine of its 11 global markets and warns non-food items face further decline
fields.body:
Tesco has been rocked by falling sales in nine of its 11 global markets, including a worse-than-expected dip in the UK as a result of the horsemeat scandal.

Britain's biggest supermarket, which launched a £1bn turnaround last year after issuing its first profit warning in 20 years, increased sales over the past three months only in Malaysia and Hungary.

The worst-performing country was Turkey, where Tesco operates 191 Kipa shops. Like-for-like sales there plunged 15.5%. In the Czech Republic, sales dived 9%; in China, where Tesco announced major expansion plans, sales fell nearly 5%.

The grocer blamed tough competition for the Czech problems, and pointed to the Chinese bird flu crisis and weak demand for pork after a safety scare for its underperformance there.

Tesco's 1,400-strong Lotus chain in Thailand was down 3%, while underlying sales at its 446-store Polish business fell more than 8%.

This year the chief executive, Philip Clarke, pulled the plug on the grocer's US venture, Fresh & Easy, which cost the group more than £1.5bn.

In the UK, which Clarke has made his focus by hiring 8,000 staff to "improve customers' experience", like-for-like sales, excluding fuel, dropped by 1%. This was on top of a 1.5% decline in the same period last year.

Sainsbury's and Waitrose have seen sales rise over the quarter.

Clarke said the slump was partly caused by the horsemeat scandal, when equine DNA was found in four Tesco products. But most of the decline was in non-food items, such as TVs and other electronics, where profit margins are wafer thin and competition from Amazon especially tough. He called for a level playing field on tax to ensure retailers with stores could compete with Amazon, which minimises its UK tax bill by routing sales through Luxembourg.

Sales of non-food items would continue to decline, Clarke warned, as Tesco attempted to reinvent itself as a more food-focused retailer. "Our plan is all about food," he added. "We decided we're going to reduce our reliance on categories that quite frankly take up a lot of space and don't take a lot of money."

He said Tesco, which was accumulating a vast land bank on which to build further stores, had dramatically reduced its ambitions. New branches would be mainly Express convenience stores rather than out-of-town superstores, he said.

Existing larger stores were undergoing a revamp to make them more appealing to customers, but Clarke said it was not going to happen overnight. "There's a lot for us to do," he conceded. "[Stores are] going to be vibrant and exciting – more of a destination than before."

As part of its push to improve the shopping experience and make use of unwanted space, Tesco is installing its independent-feeling coffee chain, Harris + Hoole, child-friendly Giraffe restaurants and artisan Euphorium bakery outlets.

Clive Black, an analyst at Shore Capital, said some of Tesco's international trading figures were truly frightening. "They've gone a step backwards," he said. "We're trying to find the floor, trying to say that Tesco has reached the bottom, and we're not sure they're there yet."

He said it was not all bad news: "Tesco is a very profitable business, with a very strong balance sheet. Management are trying to work the existing estate harder and trying to generate more cash for shareholders. But there's a lot of work to do, and investors are going to have to be patient."

He added that Clarke "undoubtedly inherited a much more challenging situation" than it appeared when he took over the reins from Sir Terry Leahy two years ago.

webTitle: Tesco revival is a long, hard road

fields.bodyText: It's just as well Philip Clarke never promised a quick fix at Tesco. The unmistakable message from Wednesday's first-quarter sales update is that revival will take years. The chief executive's boast that his plans are on track is fair only in a limited sense. The revamped stores in the UK undoubtedly look more cheery and have more staff. But so they should: Tesco is throwing £1bn of investment at Britain. Against that backdrop, it must be disappointing to see like-for-like sales fall 1%, notwithstanding the plea that a headwind was created by the sensible decision to chop big-ticket, low-margin, ranges such as electrical goods. The problem of too much floorspace is glaring and even the rapid-refresh programme envisages only 15% of the estate being treated every year. The open question is whether Tesco can hang on to its 5.2% operating margin. The target is a totem of the Clarke masterplan and the boss stuck to his guns on Wednesday. But investors, one suspects, will only truly start to believe when they see like-for-like sales rising consistently at a decent pace. If the road looks long and hard in Britain, take a look at the international picture. Low-lights included: like-for-like sales in Turkey down 15.5%, Czech Republic 9% lower, Poland 8.2% weaker and China off 4.9%. And that's after a year in which returns on capital in the international division were already weak. "How long will Tesco persist with its value-destroying international diversification?" asked Investec's Dave McCarthy the other day. Good question. At the moment, Tesco seems to regard the notion of further retreat as heretical; the exit from Fresh & Easy in the US is viewed as a special case. Hold on, though, Tesco entered China in 2004, is still losing money there almost a decade later and now like-for-like sales are evaporating. Apparently China is "strategically important market." But when?

webTitle: Economic recovery could now be on the way

fields.bodyText: Services make up three quarters of Britain's national output so the sharp increase in the June purchasing managers' index for the sector bodes well for growth, not just in the second quarter but for 2013 as a whole. The Office for Budget Responsibility predicted at the time of the budget that Britain would grow by only 0.3% this year. That now looks overly pessimistic, not just as a result of the better than expected service sector PMI – which recorded its fifth successive increase – but because other recent data have suggested that the economy has turned the corner. It is, of course, too soon to say. Britain could easily be blown off course again by events in the rest of the world. The eurozone is in recession, while activity in both the US and China is slowing. Consumers' real incomes remain under pressure as a result of prices rising faster than wages. Deficit reduction will, as the IMF noted, act as a brake on growth this year. But in the past few days there have been reports showing a pickup in the three big sectors of the economy – services, manufacturing and construction. Consumers are not exactly in party mood, but they are a lot less gloomy than they were. Inflation is coming down, which means the real income squeeze is far less powerful than it was a year ago. The service sector PMI is, though, perhaps the strongest piece of evidence that recovery is under way. The two percentage point jump in June was far bigger than expected and took the index to its highest in more than a year. The improvement was broad-based. Why is this happening? A combination of factors, in all likelihood. Four years of cheap money – bank rate at 0.5% and £375bn of quantitative easing – are having an impact. The funding for lending scheme is channelling money into the mortgage market. After years of making do, companies are having to replace bits of kit. Consumers, fed up with being fed up, are starting to spend a little more freely. Growth in the second quarter is, as a result, likely to accelerate from the 0.3% in the first three months of 2013 to perhaps 0.5% or 0.6%. Something close to 1.5% for 2013 would then look eminently feasible. Historically, that would be no great shakes and would still leave activity below its peak in early 2008. But everything's relative; it was only six weeks ago that the speculation was about a triple-dip recession.

webTitle: The wave of privatisations: in detail

fields.standfirst: Royal Mail, student loans, Urenco, search and rescue, blood plasma and banks - value, staff and possible bidders
fields.body:
Royal Mail

Value: £3bn

What stage in the process: The government has appointed Goldman Sachs and UBS to advise on the sell-off - hopefully within a year. The Communication Workers Union is mounting an anti-privatisation campaign and is balloting postal workers asking them to vote for or against the privatisation plans. The results from the ballot are due on 19 June and could lead to industrial action.

Staff: 150,000

Possible bidders: A stock market flotation in London, with staff granted shares equal to 10% of the company, is the preferred option. However, business minister Michael Fallon has said other options are still "on the table", including a sale to sovereign wealth funds or other foreign buyers.

Student loan book/Student Loans Company

Value: 1st tranche: £900m

What stage in the process: Business secretary Vince Cable revealed in March plans to sell a book of mortgage-style student loans with a face value of £900m. The market value is likely to be lower however, as the loans in question were issued between 1990 and 1998 and are mostly in arrears or deferred. The government has stated the private sector may be able to improve the collection of repayments "using their expertise".

There is a possibility the rest of the loan book, worth £45.9bn in March 2012, could follow. A BIS spokesman said the government "continues to explore options for monetising student loans".

Staff: 2,260

Possible bidders: Banks, investment funds, financial institutions

Urenco

Value: UK stake: £3bn

What stage in the process: The government put its one-third stake in the nuclear processor up for sale in April, after securing agreement from its Dutch and German partners. The Dutch government also owns a third, while Germancompanies RWE and E.On jointly own the rest. All parties are now thought to be willing to sell their stakes in the uranium enrichment company, paving the way for a potential £9bn auction. Urenco has the gas centrifugal capacity not only to fuel the 430 nuclear power plants worldwide but also to make a nuclear bomb.

Staff: 1,600 worldwide

Possible bidders: Financial buyers, most likely infrastructure investors and sovereign wealth funds. Trade buyers including France's Areva and Canada's Cameco are also likely to look at it, and a flotation has not been ruled out.

Search and rescue

Value: £1.6bn

What stage in the process: The 10-year contract has been awarded by the Department for Transport to US-based Bristow, which will take over search and rescue helicopter duties from the RAF and Royal Navy on a phased basis from April 2015. Bristow will also take on civilian search and rescue bases run by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency. The current fleet of Sea King helicopters, as flown by Prince William, will be retired. Eleven Sikorsky S-92 and 11 AgustaWestland AW189 helicopters will be located at 10 bases across the UK.

Staff: Bristow plans to employ 350 people to carry out the contract.

Bidders: Won by Bristow

Plasma Resources UK

Value: £200m

What stage in the process: Health minister Dan Poulter announced in January that the Department of Health is examining a sale of part of all of Plasma Resources UK to the private sector as "the best way for it to achieve growth." Potential investors were asked to state what level of resources they would make available, how they planned to grow operations, and how products would be developed.

Staff: 1,200 (200 in the UK, 1,000 in the US)

Possible bidders: Bioscience and healthcare companies. Baxter, Grifols and Biotest are likely to consider, as well as private equity firms.

Banks

Value: Dependent on share prices

What stage in the process: Royal Bank of Scotland and Lloyds Banking Group, bailed out in the wake of the financial crisis with £66bn of taxpayer funds, will be returned to the private sector at a point yet to be determined, but it is thought that George Osborne and David Cameron wants them fully returned to the private sector before the next election in 2015. The government could start selling off shares in the companies on a phased basis. RBS is 81% owned by the taxpayer, while Lloyds is 39% state owned. The parliamentary commission on banking standards may recommend that RBS be nationalised, then split into a good bank and a bad bank, but the government is unlikely to be supportive, partly because it could slow down the privatisation process. Shares could be sold or gifted to the public.

Staff: 227,000 (RBS: 123,000, Lloyds: 104,000)

Possible bidders: Flotation planned

webTitle: Dame Clara Furse survives grilling to secure Bank of England role

fields.bodyText: MPs have raised serious concerns about the suitability of Dame Clara Furse, a former boss of the London Stock Exchange, to sit on a powerful new body overseeing financial stability. Even so, the Treasury select committee (TSC), which subjected Furse to a grilling this week, cleared her appointment to the financial policy committee of the Bank of England. Despite its reservations about Furse, who sat on the capital and risk committee at Dutch-Belgian financial firm Fortis during the ill-fated ABN Amro takeover, the MPs concluded she had "the professional competence and personal independence" to be a member of the FPC. The endorsement of the first female member of the body set up to identify and defuse the next financial crisis followed a difficult appearance for Furse before the committee on Tuesday. She was grilled about her role on the board of Fortis, which was bailed out by Dutch, Belgian and Luxembourg taxpayers during the 2008 financial crisis. The committee said its concerns were based on her lack of awareness about demonstrating the FPC's independence from the government and the way she explained her role on the board of Fortis. The bank was involved in the takeover of Dutch rival ABN Amro along with Royal Bank of Scotland, which also needed be rescued after completing the deal during the height of the credit crunch. She would have been braced for the concerns of the committee as during her evidence she had been told by the Conservative MP Jesse Norman that her evidence was "amazingly unimpressive". He told her he was considering whether to support her appointment to the FPC. She told MPs she had learnt from her "searing" experience on the Fortis board. webTitle: UK services sector's unexpected surge boosts economy

fields.standfirst: May's CIPS/Markit survey shows all major sectors are now growing for the first time in a year
fields.body:
The economy regained some of its former vibrancy in May after a bigger than expected surge in services activity showed that all major sectors are now growing for the first time in a year.

Following figures earlier this week that found the construction and manufacturing sectors back in positive territory during May, the CIPS/Markit survey of the services sector showed it expanded more strongly than expected.

The broad-based recovery is likely to end the debate about a triple-dip recession, especially after the economy grew in the first quarter of the year by 0.3%. It is now showing every sign of outstripping that figure in the second quarter.

Markit said an increase in new business was behind much of the rise in its index of services activity to 54.9, up from April's 52.9. The index signalled a rate of growth that was the sharpest since March 2012, it said.

With sales up and the cost of production remaining steady, the profitability of the UK corporate sector should be more upbeat, but the Markit profitability index came in below the key level of 50 – the mark that separates growth from contraction.

"The latest fall in profitability was the 12th in successive survey periods, although the rate of decline was the slowest in this sequence," it said. "Where a fall in profits was reported, a number of companies blamed a combination of discounting and higher input costs. In contrast, other respondents signalled that higher sales and associated growth in turnover had supported profitability in the three months to May."

Nevertheless, firms reported that they were employing more workers, spurring a fifth straight monthly rise in services sector employment.

Alan Clarke, chief UK economist at Scotia Bank, struck a note of concern after he asked whether the bounce from last year's lows was likely to last more than a few months.

"I remain a little sceptical that this momentum can be maintained. In particular, with government spending growth about to stall and real household disposable income growth turning negative I struggle to see how this sort of pace of growth can be maintained," he said.

Some economists have argued that the recent better economic news merely reflects a rebound from the artificially low activity last year when firms, spooked by the euro crisis and the UK's double-dip recession, cut investment spending and reduced stocks.

Capital Economics, which has consistently warned that the UK faces a Japanese-style lost decade of low growth, said the figures remained subdued for an economy recovering from a severe recession, though any talk of recession was now in the past.

The firm's UK economist, Martin Beck, said: "Following a run of generally good economic news in recent weeks, May's UK CIPS/Markit report on services provides another indication that the economy may be turning a corner. The activity index rose from 52.9 to 54.9, the fifth consecutive monthly increase and the highest reading since March 2012.

"What's more, the CBI's recent services sector survey also suggested growing momentum in services activity. With May also seeing improvements in the manufacturing and construction CIPS, a weighted average of the three surveys points to quarterly GDP growth of about 0.5%.

"While such a rate would still be pretty modest for an economy emerging from a long period of recession and stagnation, signs that the recovery may be establishing some momentum are becoming more convincing."

webTitle: Britain's working classes: a far cry from the 1840s

fields.bodyText: The workshop of the world in the early years of Queen Victoria's reign has been transformed into an economy where more than eight out 10 people work in the service sector, the UK's statistical agency said. A study of every census for England and Wales since 1841 shows that almost two-thirds of the population worked in factories or on the land at the start of Britain's mid-Victorian heyday. The Office for National Statistics said 36% of the workforce was employed in manufacturing and a further 22% in agriculture and fishing, while 33% worked in services, half of them as domestic servants. By the early 1880s, more people worked in services than manufacturing although the big fall in industrial employment did not begin until the 1960s. Britain, the first country to go through an industrial revolution, was the dominant world economy in the 1840s and that strength was concentrated north of a line drawn from the Wash to the Severn Estuary. Southern England outside London was predominantly rural and poorer than the North. In its study, the ONS charts the increasing sophistication of manufacturing over 170 years, a period in which vastly improved productivity has allowed more to be produced by fewer workers. Innovations from the Bessemer process for mass-producing steel from pig iron to the microprocessor have meant modern industry is a far cry from the mills and foundries of the 1840s. By 2011, fewer than 1% of the working population were employed on farms or fishing fleets, with manufacturing accounting for a further 8.9%. The service sector accounted for 81% of the 26.5 million employees in England and Wales. The latest census shows that three times as many people work in the public sector (28.4%) as in industry. The ONS said that no part of England and Wales had more than a quarter of its workforce employed in manufacturing, with the highest concentration (24%) found in Corby in the East Midlands, where an enterprise zone with industrial parks was set up in an attempt to compensate for the decline of the steel industry. In the service industries, the highest concentration of estate agents is to be found in the London borough of Kensington and Chelsea (3.4%) and Hackney has the highest proportion of people working in the arts, entertainment and recreation sector (8.3%). Almost a quarter of people living in Oxford are employed in the education sector, compared with just under 10% for England and Wales as a whole.

webTitle: FTSE 100 falls nearly 100 points while Wall Street opens lower on jobs figures

fields.standfirst: Disappointing private payrolls data adds to investors' downbeat mood and helps push global markets lower
fields.body:
Wall Street has opened lower after disappointing jobs data, continuing the pressure on downbeat European markets.

Ahead of Friday's US non-farm payroll figures, the ADP employment report showed a 135,000 increase in private payrolls in May, up from a revised 113,000 in April but lower than the forecast 165,000.

Markets were already weak on a growing number of comments from US Federal Reserve members that its bond buying programme - a key support for share prices - might gradually come to an end. Japan's latest plan to boost its economy underwhelmed investors, pushing the Nikkei down 3.8% and taking it further into correction territory (a more than 10% drop from its peak). Ishaq Siddiqi, market strategist at ETX Capital said:

Interestingly, markets did not welcome the poor ADP release as a sign that the Federal Reserve will refrain from tapering asset purchases. US first quarter productivity was also slightly weaker, gearing the market up for a similarly weak nonfarm payrolls report on Friday.
The ADP report is not an accurate predictor of the official government payrolls report so traders are reserving judgement for now.

Dealers are also awaiting Thursday's meetings at the Bank of England and European Central Bank.

Ahead of all that, the FTSE 100 has fallen 99.11 points - or 1.5% - to 6459.47 while Wall Street is down 60 points or 0.4%. Both Germany and France have lost almost 1%.
