webTitle: Toyota recalls 242,000 Prius cars

fields.standfirst: Japanese carmaker recalls 242,000 third-generation Prius vehicles worldwide – including 5,000 in the UK – over brake fault
fields.body:
Toyota has recalled 242,000 Prius cars worldwide including 5,000 in the UK because of faulty brakes.

The company, which suffered a debilitating recall crisis in 2009/2010, said no accidents have been reported but it has received 93 complaints from customers worldwide.

Toyota will be contacting UK owners of the affected vehicles in the coming weeks by post. It will exchange the faulty part with a new one, which should take around three hours.

This is the latest in a series of car recalls affecting a number of different companies. Neil King, automotive analyst at Euromonitor, said: "Recalls seem to be so commonplace these days, I don't see it having any major impact. The only fortunate thing [for Toyota] is that at least they are not the only ones affected. There was a period when it seemed to be only Toyota." He said car recalls are getting more frequent as vehicles become increasingly technologically advanced.

On Tuesday, US group Chrysler refused to recall 2.7m older-model Jeeps, saying that US regulators' concerns about the vehicles' fuel tanks causing fires and deaths were ill-founded.

Toyota's current problem affects third generation Prius models built between March to October 2009. A company spokeswoman said recalled vehicles could experience greater stopping distances when braking because of a design flaw in a brake part.

Vibrations during driving could cause cracks in the brake pressure accumulator, she explained, allowing nitrogen gas to leak into the brake fluid, which would make the brakes less effective.

Toyota said in a statement: "The driver will become aware of the problem through a warning light illuminating on the dashboard. Should this occur, the vehicle should not be driven and owners should report the issue to their nearest Toyota Centre."

Toyota will recall 117,000 units in Japan, 91,000 in North America, 30,000 in Europe and 3,000 in Asia-Pacific.

In 2010, the Japanese company, which is a leader in gas-electric hybrid technology, recalled 433,000 hybrid vehicles, including the Prius, because of a braking software glitch.

Toyota has sold 3.6m Prius vehicles globally and more than 60,000 in the UK since the model went on sale in December 1997.

To check if your Prius is part of the recall, enter your registration number in the Toyota recall checker.

webTitle: Services sector growth: what the economists say

fields.standfirst: Experts react as survey shows larger-than-expected surge in services activity
fields.body:
Annalisa Piazza, UK analyst at Newedge Strategy

The UK services PMI survey showed further momentum in business confidence in May. The overall sentiment indicator rose by a solid two points to 54.9 in May, exceeding expectations for a more modest increase. The index is now at its highest level since late 2011 and it suggests the services sector is running at a very decent speed (not consistent with recent hard data). Given the still blurred economic situation, we are sceptical on the effective materialisation of a boom in the UK services sector near term. However, today's survey certainly shows that the mix of very accommodative monetary policy, coupled with timid signs of improvement from abroad, have a positive impact on sentiment.

Coupled with the upward surprise for the manufacturing PMI earlier this week, the survey consolidates the idea that the monetary policy committee will keep policy unchanged after this week's meeting. That said, policymakers will also have to read between the lines of recent hard data, with Q1-3 GDP rising on the back of rising inventories (and not much else) and still weak retail activity.

Low wage growth is not encouraging for future spending and the recent decline in headline inflation is well below the recent IR projections. In a nutshell, this week's survey has been encouraging but the overall picture for the UK economy is far from being clear. Caution will remain high, in our view.

James Knightley, UK economist at ING bank

Encouragingly, we have seen strong rises in the new orders components for all three series [manufacturing, construction and services] with today's service sector figure coming in at 57.2, the strongest reading since February 2010. This bodes well for economic activity in the months ahead and should ensure a relatively decent GDP print for the second quarter this year. As such, there is little prospect of any BoE [Bank of England] action tomorrow and it diminishes the likelihood of any shift in policy under Mark Carney in the next few months.

Howard Archer, chief UK economist at IHS Global Insight

The May services sector purchasing managers survey not only adds to a recent stream of improved news on the UK economy, but is among the most encouraging of the lot given the dominant role of the services sector. It now looks increasingly likely that the UK economy will grow by at least 1.0% in 2013. Still hardly great, but significantly better than seemed likely even a few weeks ago.

With the manufacturing and construction purchasing managers' surveys both showing improvement, there are encouraging signs that the UK economy stepped up a gear in May and is finally establishing a firmer footing. Indeed, the composite PMI for the services, manufacturing and construction output jumped to a 14-month high of 54.6 in May from 52.4 in April, taking it well above the 50 level that indicates flat activity.

Of course, the UK economy still faces very challenging domestic and global conditions and relapses remain very possible, so it is important not to get too carried away with the latest data.

The improved set of purchasing managers surveys for May reinforces belief that the Bank of England will sit tight on all aspects of monetary policy when the June MPC [monetary policy committee] meeting ends on Thursday. However, we still think more quantitative easing may well occur after Mark Carney takes over as governor in July. We suspect Carney will be keen to try and build up escape velocity from the economy's extended softness and will be keen to establish his presence after arriving at the start of July.

Ian Kernohan, economist at Royal London Asset Management

A clean sweep on the PMIs suggests another quarter of positive GDP growth in the UK. PMI services was particularly strong and this rebound has also been backed up by the recent CBI survey.

This presents an interesting dilemma for the new BoE governor, who appears to favour easing monetary policy further. While the economy is far from healthy, the most recent data do suggest some improvement. No doubt there will be a vigorous debate within the MPC as to whether further stimulus is required at this stage.

webTitle: Tesco chief executive defends downturn amid 'dramatically reduced ambitions'

fields.standfirst: Philip Clarke insists first-quarter sales fall is part of a plan to move away from selling consumer electronics
fields.body:
Tesco's recovery was thrown into doubt on Wednesday after UK sales fell in the first quarter.

Chief executive Philip Clarke insisted the decline was part of a plan to move away from selling consumer electronics, such as flat-screen TVs.

"Our plan is on track. We decided we're going to reduce our reliance on categories that quite frankly take up a lot of space and don't take a lot of money," Clarke said.

But he indicated he was unhappy with the drop in sales. "I couldn't sit here and say I'm happy with performance. As it happens, our plan was that we would take sales backwards this year while we make these changes." Tesco says like-for-like sales of non-food products would continue to slide throughout the year, but that would not hit group profits.

Overall sales from UK stores open longer than a year fell 1% in the three months to the end of May (excluding the impact of volatile petrol sales and VAT), marginally lower than analyst forecasts. Rivals Sainsbury's and Waitrose have both seen sales rise over a similar period. Tesco shares fell 2.8% in early trade to 354p.

webTitle: Debenhams shows off Oxford Street store revamp but analysts cautious

fields.standfirst: Concerns about current trading outweigh presentation of future plans for flagstreet site
fields.body:
Debenhams showed off plans for the future of its flagship store in London's Oxford Street on Tuesday, but the reaction seems underwhelming so far.

The retailer's shares are down 2.05p at 92.6p as analysts fretted about its trading and were cautious about the revamp. Cantor Fitzgerald's Kate Calvert and Freddie George wrote:

Management held an analyst visit to see the vision of its future flagship Oxford Street store, which is work-in-progress and due to complete in November. The refurbishment is long overdue and while a pre-tax return on investment of 8% does not sound the most exciting from a shareholders perspective, it overlooks the longer term soft benefits a flagship store gives in terms of show-casing the brand and setting the standards both in the UK and internationally. However, these softer benefits do take time to monetise.
In the meantime, we remain concerned over current trading and the fact that UK profits remain under pressure over the next year. We believe the shares are ahead of themselves and reiterate our sell recommendation.

Retail analyst Nick Bubb gave more detail on the proposed upgrade of the store:

We well remember the Fitch-designed "galleria" concept of the 1986 era, which carved out the huge central atrium, but over 25 years on and it is all a bit old hat and Debenhams' local competitors such as John Lewis and House of Fraser (quite apart from the likes of Forever 21 and Primark) have invested tons recently in their own flagship stores.
So Debenhams is now pulling out all the stops, to impress the judges, and the amazing new "kinetic facade" of moving steel plates for Debenhams Oxford Street (paid for by the landlords British Land) has been designed by the famous US artist Ned Kahn (as seen at the Zurich Science Museum and countless public buildings in the US). And the two front corners of the building are to have multi-floor, glass-fronts cut into them, although the store revamp is meant to be finished by November and that work hasn't even started yet...Behind the scenes, analysts were shown all the other building work going on, however, which includes a new glass-ceilinged 5th floor, to be devoted to Kidswear. Debenhams were coy about what they expect the revamp to do to sales, although they expect an 8% return on investment on the capital expenditure of £25m, albeit so far sales have fallen by around 10% because of all the disruption. Debenhams was also coy about current trading, ahead of the next update, on 27 June.

webTitle: FTSE falls back on Fed bond buying worries and Japan growth concerns

fields.standfirst: Tesco dips on disappointing update but Tate & Lyle climbs following Investec buy note
fields.body:
Leading shares have fallen back on continuing concerns that the US Federal Reserve may soon turn off the money tap and disappointment about Japan's plans to stimulate its economy.

Comments from a number of Fed members - most recently Dallas Fed president Richard Fisher and Kansas City's Esther George - have suggested its bond buying programme could be slowed down. The markets have been banking on central banks continuing their measures to boost the global economy, and any signs that these actions could be coming to an end tend to be taken badly.

So with Japan's latest proposals to lift its own economy falling short of expectations, the FTSE 100 has fallen 48.12 points to 6510.46. Mike McCudden, head of derivatives at stockbroker Interactive Investor, said:

With tomorrow's rate verdicts from the European Central Bank and the Bank of England, then Friday's non-farm payrolls, there's scope for traders to get another [boost] before the week is out but at least for now it's an air of caution that's prevailing and the bears seem to be battling for control.

Tesco has lost 13.85p to 350.6p after its trading update missed City forecasts, while a number of companies saw their shares go ex-dividend, including National Grid, down 34p at 756.5p, and WPP, 18p lower at £11.02.

Aberdeen Asset Management has dropped 20.3p to 443.6p in the wake of Tuesday's news that director Anne Richards had sold more than £6m worth of shares. UBS has removed the company from its key call list but remain buyers.

Arm has recovered 8p to 932p after recent weakness on worries about growing competition in its key tablet market from Intel. Bank of America Merrill Lynch said:

Simon Segars, Arm's upcoming chief executive, presented at our global tech conf yesterday. When asked about Intel's win at Samsung for a 10'' tablet, Mr Segars commented that Samsung has a tradition to use multiple suppliers and that not all Android apps run on x86 CPUs, potentially hindering user experience.
Arm recently raised its 2020 royalty revenues compound annual growth rate guidance. Mr Segars
explained that Arm raised its guidance due to 1) expected share gains in existing and new markets, 2) higher royalty rates and 3) confidence in the underlying growth rate of Arm's core markets. We also believe Arm gave this guidance probably knowing fully well that Intel had won a tablet socket at Samsung. This indicates, in our view, how confident Arm's management is in the long term growth trajectory of its business.

We see the recent weakness in the stock as a particular buying opportunity as we believe that Arm's ecosystem is likely to prevail long term.

Wolseley is 15p better at £31.60 following Tuesday's decline on caution about its European business.

Tate and Lyle has climbed 4p to 836p after Investec moved from hold to buy. Analyst Martin Deboo said:

With the shares back to around 830p post-prelims, having under-performed the late spring rally by 8%, we once again see an attractive entry point to this story. We resume a buy recommendation, at an increased 900p target price. Speciality food ingredients (SFI) growth looks set to resume with sucralose back on track. Plus we think the market would applaud a consolidating move in SFI. What's not to like? Low overall growth in 2014 and downside risk in bulk ingredients, most obviously. However bulk guidance feels sensibly cautious and has now been ingested by the market.

Moneysupermarket.com has added 5.3p to 213p despite news that founder Simon Nixon - who moved to a non-exec role in April - planned to sell a 14.8% stake in the business. The company is also returning £70m to shareholders with a special dividend of 12.92p a share. It also issued an upbeat trading statement. David Reynolds at Jefferies said:

Investors will welcome the increased liquidity, the punchy return of cash and whilst the brief trading update 'in line and revenues up in excess of 10% year on year' won't blow one's socks off - we look for 10.4% revenue growth for 2013 - it is in line.

But hedge fund group Man has slumped nearly 11%, down 12.6p to 103.9p, after it said its flagship product AHL saw its net asset value fall by 6.1% last week, one of its biggest weekly declines. UBS cut from buy to neutral and reduced its target price from 130p to 110p:

(i) AHL has had an 12% pull back from its recent peak, leading to a significant cut to earnings, but also reducing the probability of flows turning (ii) Japanese retail's risk appetite may have been negatively impacted by the recent bout of volatility (iii) valuation on our mark to market estimates is less compelling.

Peter Lenardos at RBC Capital Markets said:

We believe that AHL is long the Nikkei 225. In the week to 3 June, the Nikkei is off 6.2%.

There was also talk that AHL was on the wrong side of US treasury bonds.
